docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama has blamed many factors for the stalling of his health care overhaul, from the recent special election in Massachusetts that deprived Democrats of their supermajority in the Senate to his own failure to better explain the legislation to the American people.
docs.abstract: Lobbying has been a major factor in the fate of the health care overhaul, but what President Obama did not mention in his State of the Union address was that many lobbyists actually worked to support his health care overhaul, not oppose it.
docs.snippet: Lobbying has been a major factor in the fate of the health care overhaul, but what President Obama did not mention in his State of the Union address was that many lobbyists actually worked to support his health care overhaul, not oppose it.

docs.lead_paragraph: A dispute between insurers and health care providers is a reminder that they have a shared interest in quality patient care at a fair price.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States has suspended its evacuations of critically injured Haitians until a dispute over who will pay for their care in Florida and other states is settled.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even before Senator-elect Scott Brown's stunning victory last week in the Massachusetts special election, there was no shortage of advice on simpler approaches to health care legislation. Earlier this month in The Wall Street Journal, the editorial columnist Peggy Noonan suggested one fix. ''The public in 2009 would have been happy to see a simple bill that mandated insurance companies offer coverage without respect to previous medical conditions,'' Ms. Noonan wrote. ''The administration could have had that -- and the victory of it -- last winter.''
docs.abstract: Wall Street Journal columnist Peggy Noonan recently wrote that public in 2009 would have been happy to see simple health care bill that mandated insurance companies offer coverage without respect to previous medical conditions; law that prohibits discrimination for pre-existing conditions by health insurers is anything but simple, opening Pandora's box of additional required legislation that would resemble parts of Senate bill (M)
docs.snippet: Even before Senator-elect Scott Brown's stunning victory last week in the Massachusetts special election, there was no shortage of advice on simpler approaches to health care legislation.     Earlier this month in The Wall Street Journal, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: If Democrats break down their major health care legislation into components that could be approved separately, the first bill up for consideration could be a proposal to end the exemption from federal antitrust laws that insurers have enjoyed since 1945. The House Judiciary Committee, led by Representative John Conyers Jr., right, Democrat of Michigan, has approved such a bill, and the full House may take action on it early next month, aides to Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday.
docs.abstract: House Judiciary Committee, led by Rep John Conyers Jr, approves bill that would end exemption from federal antitrust laws that health insurers have enjoyed since 1945; Conyers photo (M)
